text: Well, I think one of the, actually there are two aspects to it. The first one, which is the most basic one, is the timeframe, as I mentioned already. You know, actually timeframes already got a bad rap in the recent years. A lot of CTAs were abandoned by investors because they think, hey, where's the trend? We're waiting for momentum to happen. It never happened. But that is typically because a lot of transform funds were using a fairly long look back period. 11 months or 12 months seem to be a typical period, maybe three months. It seems that for crisis after strategy, for tail head strategy, actually a shorter timeframe is what is most effective as evidenced by our strategy and other similar crisis after funds. So that's the first aspect. It is really the optimal duration that really sets the tone. The second aspect to answer is, I think the basic strategy should still be fairly simple. The trend is not difficult to define. But it is the risk. Risk management, that can be quite complicated. And that's where we apply our machine learning strategy. We do not use the machine to discover trends. We use the machine to tell us the probability that the trend will continue. The machine learning system can fetal the trading signal generated by the base system, or it can recommend a lower capital allocation to a trade if it judges the probability to be too low. Now, this is the first aspect. It's not a concept that we invented. I know that Marcus Lopax-Dicardo had been writing about it in his best silence for a while. And we just took that approach to apply it to a practical trading strategy.
